Talk to Her (Hable con ella) is Pedro Almodovar's sixteenth film as a director. It is difficult to describe the plot of the film as it travels back and forth in time, ranging from intense moments of psychological insight to an amusing silent film sequence, and I would loath to give away any of the entertaining and twisting plot development so characteristic of Almodovar's films. It primarily focuses on the relationship between two men: the antisocial, sexually ambiguous and lovingly charming Benigno (Javier Camara) and stalwart but emotional sensitive Marco (Dario Grandinetti) as they attend their respective women in permanent sleep at the hospital. A chance encounter at the theatre leads to a later encounter where a seemingly casual friendship grows into a desperate bond. Solitude is the predominant theme of this lively, entertaining and provoking film. There are countless moments for the protagonists to contemplate their life and loves alone. Despite its serious subject matter, Almodovar's masterful handling creates an entertaining story filled with wit and humor. The characters possess compelling quirks and are wonderfully realised in a stunning cast. Amazing performances are given from peripheral characters such as the ballerina instructor, Katerina (Geraldine Chaplin) and the caretaker (Chus Lampreave). Meticulous Almodovar fans will enjoy spotting cameo appearances by past stars from his films. This is an intricate and ceaselessly compelling film that should attract a wide mature audience.
The film begins and ends in the theatre. The performances there suitably reflect the dilemmas evoked in the film and the relationships of the men with their women. The fascinating thing about this film is the way that a story between the men is handled on the surface whilst a subconsciouss story is told by the women in their comas. Gradually, through the use of flashbacks, their story emerges and we are led to image what is happening in their heads while in the hospital. It is interesting to note that the silent film sequence was originally written by Almodovar to be made into a full-length silent film. What we are given is a delightful though shocking glimpse of what that would have been. It is touching to see Almodovar's small nod of tribute to Michael Cunningham's The Hours which is a novel he states he really enjoyed. The film characteristically stretches our ideas of high drama and the far-reaching regions of sexuality. This is a beautiful film to follow from Almodovar's internationally successful All About My Mother (Todo Sobre Mi Madre).

Pedro Almodvars 14th feature Talk to Her (Hable con ella, 2002) is very special. For me it is one of a handful of incontestably great films made this side of the Millenium. My first Almodvar, I saw it some 10 years ago and seeing every one since then from Pepi, Luci, Bom (1980) right through to Im So Excited! (2013) has simply confirmed my initial awe-struck reaction. The basic thematics of Almodvars worldview have been spelled out with admirable and thoroughly consistent artistic integrity over 19 films in almost 4 decades. A few words need to be said about this worldview before I get to the film.

Almodvar is deeply connected with post-Franco Spanish society and the way a country and its people adapted (and are still adapting) from fascism to democracy. Franco died in 1975 and the first General Election was held in 1977. Technically Spain democratized overnight, but in reality the transition was long and torturous, the tension between right and left which led to the Spanish Civil War (1936-39) extending through to this very day. Almodvar has always been on the left wing of the political spectrum and his feature films made in the wake of the collapse of a dictatorship can be read as both an attack and a celebration. The attack is on Francoism, a male chauvinist patriarchy perpetuated by the state-sponsored Catholic Church, brutally upheld by the justice system and by twisted authority figures. The celebration is of freedoms won with the advent of democracy including freedom of speech, freedom of movement, rights for women and sexual liberation. Sometimes the politics are stated explicitly. At the end of Live Flesh (1997) Victor exclaims, The Spanish have lost their fear and the general thrust of any given Almodvar film is the birth of freedom and love out of restriction and hate, the surge from darkness to light (from fascism to democracy) lying in the background even of the films in which politics and history appear to be absent.

The two main themes running through this attack and celebration are transition and identity. Everything in Almodvar is fluid and in a state of flux with a country and its people forever changing and searching for some kind of identity to move forward and achieve stability/security. This transition and identity is addressed in three key areas; in the area of politics and society (what does being Spanish mean?); in the area of the body and sexuality (as a repressed homosexual growing up under Franco we can understand how important sexual emancipation was both for Almodvar and also a great many other people irrespective of their sexual orientation); and in the artistic creative process itself (writing as well as filmmaking as expressed by a fascination with story-telling, cinema history and a very knowing postmodernism). The films variously focus on any one of these areas without ever losing sight of the other two. All About My Mother (made in 1999 and the film immediately preceding Talk to Her) miraculously manages to balance all three in almost equal proportion, but with a subtle emphasis given to matters bodily. In that film the character Agrado utters a statement from the very heart of Almodvars worldview. Justifying her trans-sexuality (the embodiment of transience) she says: You are more authentic the more you resemble what youve dreamed you are. The resounding applause accorded her by the audience and by Almodvar himself of course tells us that this director asserts the right of everyone to be able to be who they want to be in an emancipated state in a world without a closet.

In Talk to Her Almodvar shifts the emphasis almost completely onto transition and identity search within the body with all four central characters existing in closets of isolation/loneliness either of their own making or imposed by external circumstances. The character of the dance teacher Katerina (Geraldine Chaplin) states the landscape of this film most clearly when she describes a projected ballet she is planning to stage entitled Trenches concerning the bodies of dead soldiers from which souls emerge as ballerinas: From the body emerges the soul, from death emerges life, from the male emerges the female, from the earth emerges the ethereal, the impalpable, the ghostly. This concern with body makes the film by far the deepest this director has made with metaphysical meditation on matters of life and death, love and loss, being with people and being alone, being and non-being, all replacing his trademark hyper-active, sexed-up, gender-bending melodramatics. Almodvar has never been entirely without weight of course and I don't want to downplay the success of his other masterpieces (which I take to be The Law of Desire [1987], Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown [1988], Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down! [1989], Live Flesh [1997] and Volver [2006]), but there is a deeply impressive intellectual rigor here along with a heaviness (especially in the final third) which is intensely moving and all the more effective for being rendered with such clarity. What follows contains spoilers.

The secret to the success of this film lies in its very tight binary narrative structure which informs how the characters develop throughout. Everything falls into either matching or opposing pairs which conveys the impression that nothing is finite, that characters and events are profoundly affected by and connected with each other on a subliminal level. The film is book-ended by two Pina Bausch ballets which act as metaphors for the main story, the first of which (Caf Mller [1978]) introduces our two couples and the second (Masurca fogo [1998]) celebrates the start of a new pairing, two of our characters having died in the course of events. In Caf Mller two ballerinas dance out their psychosis across a caf to Henry Purcells Plaint from The Fairy Queen (O, let me forever weep) while a man clears tables and chairs out of their path. In the audience two men sit next to each other. Strangers, they are a nurse Benigno (Javier Cmara) who is bored, and a journalist Marco (Daro Grandinetti) who is crying. The ballet pre-figures the scenario of the whole film which is concerned with two comatose women whose massive obstacles (the tables and chairs) the two men try to remove. The men are introduced as binary opposites. We see one man talks a lot, but does not move. He stays in the same place. The other man is moving a lot, but does not talk (Almodvar). Benigno is a 24 year old virgin who has spent his life at a womans bedside, first his mother who he nursed for 20 years and now his patient Alicia (Leonor Watling), a young ballerina put into a coma by a car accident and under his care in hospital. Marco is a travel writer who has spent his whole life on the move, a point emphasized by his introduction on a Body Trek exercising machine, his sweat linking on from the tears cried at the ballet. He likes really desperate women in trouble (Almodvar) and the film shows his relationship with two women; his ex-girlfriend ngela (Elena Anaya) who we see in flashback as the factor that has kept him on the move (she was a heroin addict who couldn't stay in Madrid); and the bullfighter Lydia (Rosario Flores) whose loneliness he emphasizes with when he sees her attacked by an evil talk show TV presenter (Loles Len). Their romance is cut short when Lydia is gored and put into a coma. She is admitted to the same hospital as Alicia and it is there that the long central part of the film takes place as Marco meets Benigno and the pair embark on a friendship.

In the hospital time moves backwards and forwards with flashbacks within flashbacks which are hard to summarize, but its clear there are two comatose victims, two men who want to help and two stories which are titled on the screen, Lydia and Marco and Alicia and Benigno. These parallel each other especially in two more metaphors which convey the emotional state of the two men and their conditions of loneliness. Marco is still pining for ngela and his sadness is visualized through a song (Caetano Veloso at a house party singing Cucurrucuc Paloma, a song about grief for a love lost) as he explains his love sickness to Lydia. Benignos mental state is expressed through a startling 7 minute silent film entitled Shrinking Lover which I will come to later. Needless to say, that too is constructed in binary terms. Both men leave the hospital at the same point in the film, Marco released from his bond to Lydia by the realization that Lydia had assumed a relationship with her ex-lover one month before she was gored and Benigno released from the hospital because it has been found that he has raped Alicia leaving her pregnant in the process. Both men are left alone, Marco resumes his lonely travels (to Jordan) while Benigno resumes his static existence, this time in a prison cell. The equilibrium is broken by Marco finding out about Lydias subsequent death which prompts a return to balance as he returns to Madrid to help his friend in prison. From this point the film stops jumping around and assumes absolute linearity until the end. Therein lies the weight of the film as we explore the friendship of two men and their concern for Alicia. In another binary opposite just as Lydia dies so Alicia wakes up. She comes to during childbirth, a fact that Marco has to conceal from Benigno. But three people awake upsets the balance again and Benigno commits suicide thinking he is reuniting himself with Alicia in the world of the ethereal. Actually, his spirit has passed over to Marco (shown to stunning effect in the interview scene in prison) as Marco takes over his life, moving into his apartment, falling in love with Alicia and eventually uniting with her at the end in the theater watching Masurca fogo with the title Mario and Alicia shown on the screen. The ballet closes off the films wonderful symmetries as two dancers, a man and a woman face up to each other and a prospective end to their loneliness.

The binary nature of the narrative and the feeling that everything is inter-connected with the actions of one character affecting those of another in the impulse towards some kind of ethereal equilibrium wherein everyone can feel secure is the perfect way to state flux and within that a declaration of sadness, of melancholy (Almodvar) in the human condition because this security stays forever tantalizingly out of reach for all of us. It is remarkable how all the characters, not just the four principles are defined in terms of transient loneliness. The nurses around Benigno all have their problems  Matilde (Lola Dueas) is a single mother whose husband has just walked out on her while Rosa (Mariola Fuentes) quietly burns a torch for Benigno. Alicias father (Helio Pedregal) is a psychiatrist widower, the concierge of Benignos apartment building (Chus Lampreave) is sad the media didn't come around after Benignos arrest to liven up her life, and even the films only bad character, the talk show presenter is left alone on the set, Lydia having (quite rightly) walked off.

Almodvar very carefully delineates the nature of the loneliness affecting each of the main characters which reveals even more binary combinations. Lydias loneliness is the loneliness of a female bullfighter alone in a male chauvinist world who has to constantly prove herself by taking increasing risks (tackling 6 bulls at once) while the gossips pounce on her sleeping with fellow matador Nio de Valencia (Adolfo Fernndez). She is presented as her fathers son in the way she attempts to succeed in a world where her father had failed (he had only been a banderillero, not a matador). Conversely Benigno is presented as his mothers daughter as Javier Cmaras remarkable performance draws out so exquisitely. He has spent his life beside the bed of a woman and has been denied the usual psycho-sexual development of a man. He has been feminized just as Lydia has been masculinized. Marco also has his share of gender confusion. He is attracted to women in trouble (close to death) because he wants to protect them, to mother them. It is Marco who cries constantly, in the theater, when he kills the snake in Lydias house, at the house party. It is Marco who is the woman in the relationship with Lydia conveyed in long car rides where it is he who does all the talking, not Lydia. Lydia is the quiet masculine non-talker who is defined most of all in the corrida where she is the picture of loneliness as she tames a bull to a sad melody on the soundtrack. The dying bull circling in slow motion, spiked with spears and dripping with blood is the very picture of loneliness which Marco is attracted to, the bull (a male cow) of course symbolizing Lydia. It could also symbolize Marco himself, his attraction to women who suffer writing large his own suffering. For Almodvar gender and sexuality are always fluid with no cast iron definition possible over something which is so transient.

The main catalyst for transition and identity search is Benigno who proves to be the independent variable in the experiment. Marco, Lydia and Alicia all have normal lives which have been knocked out of kilter by external events. Lydias vocation may be unusual, but she is a woman doing what she has to do to live in a mans world, having affairs and pursuing a career. Alicia is a young girl, a future ballerina enjoying the prime of her youth. Both are knocked into comas, into assuming different identities. In binary terms Lydias loneliness is defined before her accident while Alicias is defined after she wakes up to find herself a different person in a different world. Marcos loneliness is also nothing unusual. He has had his share of sexual relationships and is also pursuing a successful career. Lydia is beyond help and eventually dies (like the old Francoism which bullfighting symbolizes?), but Benigno profoundly affects both Marco and Alicia simply because he does not belong to the average world. He lives in a parallel world which has its own rules which makes him an innocent in the real world. His warmth and love is what finally makes Marco able to talk to her (to Alicia). Marco had been unable to talk to Lydia after she had fallen into a coma, thinking that state to be death rather than life. Benigno feels the opposite way, that coma is life albeit a changed one and that victims deserve the love and affection they would receive as if they are walking around and talking. Marco at first thinks (as most of us surely do) its crazy to conduct monolog conversations with a coma victim, but when he leaves the hospital he sits next to Alicia and says, Hello Alicia, Im alone again Benignos craziness has worked on Marco transforming him into a man who also falls in love with a coma victim. Indeed after Marco returns from Jordan he in a sense becomes Benigno by taking over his life (his apartment) and his love (Alicia). This is shown quite wonderfully in the prison interview where the pair are sitting opposite each other and Almodvar has his camera on a track. Both are sealed in their own little cubicle worlds looking at each other. As the camera shifts to focus 90 degrees on one the reflection of the others head falls over the head of the others, first Marcos over Benignos and then (after the camera slides left) Benignos over Marcos. Its as if they are sharing each others feelings, bonding as one person, but its also as if they are exchanging identities. Marco is shifting his terminal loneliness over onto the doomed Benigno while Benigno is shifting his kindness and caring over onto Marco. Marcos assumption of Benignos life and eventual romantic pairing with Alicia is then Benignos as well, for his spirit, his very essence now resides inside Marcos body.

Benignos loneliness is touchingly conveyed. Put simply, the man cares but has nobody to care for him. He has devoted his whole life to bedside care and what we see of his life in this film away from the bedside shows him to be unselfishly living the life of the person he is caring for. We see him bored at the opening ballet and we see him disturbed by the silent film he sees. He experiences both because he is living out Alicias life as she would want to live it, and he simply wants to recount the experiences to her at her bedside. We see him in his apartment trying to arrange it how Alicia would like it and he discusses interior designs with her with the idea they are going to live there together and he even tells Marco he wants to marry her. His life is completely sacrificed to Alicia and his loneliness (because she cant respond) is underlined again and again both in the script (Ive hugged very few people in my life) and in the mise-en-scene (his apartment is the saddest of a series of borderline locations which dominate this film). Marco says the special shoes Alicia wears on bed look like Ibizan shoes to which Benigno reveals he has never been to Ibiza. In fact he has never been anywhere and the only way he can travel is in the mind as he reads Marcos travel guides in prison. He empathizes profoundly with a Cuban woman seeing how time passes and nothing happens. I thought it was me, and when we hear in voice-over about his one and only trip (his suicide) the camera focuses on a photo of the guidebook cover with the woman leaning out of the window.

Benignos purity in his own world which translates as craziness in the real world is placed center of attention by Almodvar who here does something he also did in Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down! He takes a social taboo (in the earlier film sexual abduction, in this film rape) and pushes it as far as it is permissible to go to state the case that human sexual desire is rooted in nature before society and religion comes along to impose rules which repress it, a repression which (Almodvar thinks) ultimately can be more damaging than the original desire itself. Benigno is possibly the purest, the most beautiful character in any Almodvar film and his actions are shown to be those of a kind, warm-hearted, loving man. His rape is a crime which is duly punished, but what crime is it when the outcome is so overwhelmingly positive? In effect he wakes Alicia up and gives her a new shot at life along with Marco.

As well as underlining the positive effect of Benignos action Almodvar contextualizes and puts his crime down to acute sexual repression. First, he visits Alicias home and is interviewed by her psychoanalyst father. The doctor asks him what the problem is and Benigno answers loneliness. It is here we find out about his peculiar life, that he is a virgin and that he took care of his mother for 20 years who was lazy rather than sick. She could have got out of bed if she had wanted to but chose not to, using and in effect abusing her son in the process. This smothering mother relationship is accompanied by a suggested antipathy for his father who walked out on them both. It doesnt need a psychoanalyst to diagnose an Oedipus complex here and it becomes clear as the film develops that Benignos psycho-sexual development has been arrested at the mother love stage and has not been allowed to develop beyond that. Also bed-ridden, Alicia is an obvious mother surrogate, a point underlined strongly in the silent film he sees and later relates to her.

In interview Almodvar has pointed out that on the surface the silent film (shot in b/w German expressionist style and set in 1924, the year of Langs Die Nibelungen and Murnaus The Last Laugh) serves two purposes. First, it hides what is going on in the hospital. Almodvar loves his character as a friend and just as we don't always want to see everything our friends do, so he cant show Benigno raping Alicia. If he did show it our sympathy for the character would be lost. Second, the silent film on one level actually inspires Benigno to rape Alicia  The film makes him recognize his desire and makes it real for him (Almodvar). Almodvar sees him as an innocent living an alternative reality with no sexual orientation at all. Watching the erotic film connects him with his libido and disturbs him deeply (he says so). It inspires him to commit an act which in the real world is a crime, but in his alternative reality is an act of love.

Under the surface though, the film is deeply symbolic and explains Benignos Oedipus complex-related sexual repression through a binary double metaphor. First, note the title Shrinking Man. The film is about the loss of potency, aka castration anxiety. The film shows a young couple, Amparo (Paz Vega) and Alfredo (Fele Martnez). Amparo is a scientist perfecting a new diet drug while her rich but idle (ie; impotent) boyfriend (Alfredo representing Benigno) looks on. He feels his manhood threatened by his brilliant partner and drinks the potion to prove his potency. But the drug causes him to shrink and as he does so there is a barely-perceptible dissolve as Amparo turns momentarily into his mother (Sonia Grande). The tiny Alfredo/Benigno returns to the mother-fold, but the mother is a monster and he hides out in his toy train set. He regresses back to his childhood, or interpreted another way the potion has revealed the real child within Alfredo/Benigno. Eventually Amparo rescues him, putting him into her handbag (an obvious vaginal symbol which pre-figures the real vagina he soon encounters). We notice the mother and Amparo resemble each other. The couple check into room 15 of the Hotel Youkali, so named after a Kurt Weill tango whose words reveal the loneliness of poor Alfredo/Benigno, Youkali being a refuge from the real world:

Youkali, it is the land of our desires, / Youkali it is happiness.
It is pleasure  / But it is a dream, a folly.
There is no Youkali. / And life goes on, weariness everyday
But the poor human soul / looks everywhere to forget it.
To leave the earth, / To find the mystery.
We dream on earth / To live on some Youkali.

In the room Amparo lays little Alfredo/Benigno on the bed before going to sleep. The little man pulls back the bed cover to reveal Amparos (to him) huge naked body which he takes delight in exploring. After climbing the mountains of her breasts he plunges south into the enchanted forest of her pubic hair. The camera is now square between Amparos legs looking at an enormous vagina which Alfredo plays with much to his ladys delight. The film finishes with Alfredo/Benigno diving into the inviting orifice to Benignos words as he relates the story, And little Alfredo stays inside her forever. We then see in color what looks like sperm connecting (or perhaps disconnecting) with an egg. Obviously the film which Benigno has seen and which we see as he relates it to Alicia is a double metaphor both for Benigno raping Alicia and for Benigno returning to his mothers womb. He is disenchanted with the cold reality of life, seeks escape in Alicia, but because his psycho-sexual development has been arrested at mother love, his Youkali, the land of [his] desires, is ultimately his mother. His loneliness is so acute that his subconscious desire is to return to his mothers womb, or to wish never to have been born, hence staying inside her forever.

The location for a statement on transition and identity happening within the human body gets perfect visualization in room 15 of Hotel Youkali. The human body becomes a transient location to equal all the other borderline locations that appear throughout the film. The film plays out in locations connected with transition, especially the transit from life to death  inside cars (Alicias coma is car crash-induced), the corrida, the prison, the graveyard, and especially the hospital where coma is the exact definition of being in transit. Other borderline locations are hotels  Lydias and Amparo/Alfredos hotels are both refuges from the hostile world; the theater and the dance studio  places where reality is transposed into an imitation of reality in poetic terms; and the homes of the characters which none of them properly inhabit. Lydia cant bear to stay in her house and asks to be taken to a hotel. Marco is always traveling and his apartment his defined by a huge world map on the wall suggesting perpetual travel. Benignos home is beside Alicias bed, not his apartment which resembles a home under construction. Alicias home is a psychiatrists waiting room where people come to find out where their lives are taking them. The only location in the whole film to have any warmth or sense of permanence is Alicias room with its carefully-arranged lights, pictures and ornaments. As Benigno looks at it we understand this is the Youkali for which he longs, but of course Alicia is put into a coma before he can get a chance. The sense of permanent danger is also hinted at by the book Alicia had been reading laying beside her bed  David Grubbs The Night of the Hunter, a classic story of childhood innocence threatened. The ultimate borderline location is the body itself - the bull fighter, the car crash victim, the sad lonely lover defining his life by protecting his lover, and the lonely man about to commit suicide because he can't take it any longer.

A profound meditation on transition and change mainly in the human body (politics are hinted at through the Francoist past bearing down on the next generation through Lydias efforts to be her father through bullfighting and Benignos domineering mother who we hear but never see; while cinematic post-modernism is addressed through the inter-textual pastiche of the Baush ballets and the silent film), do not think for a moment this is a gloomy art film. The first half is surprising light and funny and 'Shrinking Lover' is a superb mixture of comedy and surreal fantasy which is better than anything Fellini ever came up with. Thanks to a roster of superb performances, all the characters emerge as fully-rounded and warmly sympathetic with Javier Cmara giving an awe-inspiring performance at the very heart of Almodvars extraordinary film managing the transition in his character from light, amiable and amusing life to dark impending 'death' with consummate mastery. Javier Aguirresarobes bright and extremely beautiful cinematography and a wonderfully sensitive musical score (especially the amazing string quartet score for Shrinking Lover) by Alberto Iglesias also help Almodvar achieve a film which is to my way of thinking as near to perfection as it is possible to get. Strongly recommended.

Visual/Sound and General Artistry --- This film comes with nearly every "frame" seeming as if it were "painted".  The compositions are so well designed, making for an intensely pleasurable visual experience, texturally rich.  This is a visual masterpiece.  In addition, the inclusion of one of film making's most "memorable" scenes (you decide which one that is) makes it a film to remember for life.  Be sure to watch for the use of orange/pink/maroon throughout the picture!  The sound track is amazing integrated with the imagery, making a most cohesive film experience, with the camera moving in and out, and around, as music changes and shifts appropriately, yet never in any staid kitchy manner.  The film draws you in throughout!

Conceptually --- The script behind this film comes with a gripping plot, though very disturbing to many.  But it is laced with a unique humanistic dusting of compassion, examining (or exposing) human beings' vulnerabilities in the face of our human condition that causes us to search for connections and love.  This carefully constructed script, with great editing work, deserves attention and several viewings over time.  Enjoy!

Two men caring for women in comas.  One of them is a sick, obsessed person who stalked the woman before she had her accident. The plot is intensely played out within a powerful, intricately romantic storyline. Rose bouquets should be given out to Leonor Watlin (as Alicia) and Rosario Flores (as Lydia Gonzlez) for their complex performances. Superb work was done by Javier Cmara (as Benigno) and Dario Grandinetti (as Marco).

Yes, extreme intimacy surrounds all romantic discourse. And yes, richly-textured dialogue elevates the film. We achieve catharsis early on; our emotions are wrung out by Act II; we grasp unto eroticism as if it were our lifeboat. Perhaps it is. Who am I to say? The flashbacks convey to us like revolving mirrors flashing back in time - the unique history of each woman. We know these women as if they were our sisters. Lydia is so badly gored that she dies in her coma. Alicia becomes pregnant while comatose and has a stillborn baby; Beningo is charged with rape, sent to prison, and later commits suicide - unable to cope with his guilt. Superior tragedy merits high marks. The denouement is complete in all respect. Passion is not sacrificed. The complex theme of forced love (rape) by Beningo upon Sylvia is handled directly by Almodvar without pretense. It happened; there are severe tragic consequences to the act. However, there is hope Sylvia once she recovers. Marco protects that hope by not telling Benigno about her recovery prior to his suicide. Dramatic irony implodes in front of our very eyes. Act III secretly plays out her denouement, followed by a descrescendo, then by the subtle irony that it is now Marcol watching over Alicia at her dance concert.

Applause must go to the director, cast, and film crew for assembling a superior work of art - that suggests to one and all that lovely, delicate themes are to be held dear - even to those who remain comatose. Love spreads her silken wings wherever and whenever - she so desires. Compassion resonates herein. The dove flutters just above the storyline to ensure - as in the superb romantic film Amelie (in French, 2001)  - that heroines do possess noblequalities, even when struck down, that reveal much about their feminine souls. Pure romance even in a clinical setting, even while the dreams of a patient may be enhanced by contact with a kind soul - becomes our connection to this beautiful story; we invest emotions, and the film rewards us. Romance like a dove in flight has left her pallor on us by displaying Alica in her ballerina pose. All classical unities were adhered to.

I saw that "Talk to Her" was a foreign language Academy Award winner and that got my interest.  I was surprised to discover that it was not even nominated for the Best Foreign Language Oscar. If you've read other reviews you probably know why there is such a strong feeling pro or con on this movie.  After some degree of soul searching I acknowledged that the director, Pedro Almodovar, did a brilliant job.  I also acknowledged that the sequence of events were impressive but still fictionally created to achieve some sort of a purpose.  I finally came to the conclusion that, if anyone wanted to make a movie with this theme then nobody could have done a better job than the outstanding product delivered by Almodover.

On the positive side, the acting is very good to excellent.  The medical aspects seemed to have been fairly well researched.  I liked the meaning of the title of the movie.  There was always something happening or just about to happen to keep our interest as well as our curiosity focussed.  There are the subtle aspects of dialogue and scenes which come back to us with the realization that everything was put together so completely.  Of all of those subtleties, I liked the chapter titles that seemed so innocuous until we get to the very end and see the final chapter title.  In that chapter title, Pedro Almodovar come up with a conclusion of our ownwhich enabled the movie to continue in our minds.  The director also covered himself well in this journey into extreme immorality by getting us all comfortable with the morality of our key players.  When the first real clue of abomination unfolded most of us, I guess, were going to stay with the movie because we were invested in these people.  The outcome is the hard part to deal with but, again, Almodovar covers his steps very well and guides us to a choice of negative/negative or negative/positive.  (I suppose some might think positive/positive but I don't think that way).  I was emotionally drained and then I saw the last chapter title.

This is not a film that I could recommend to anyone I know.  Frankly, I'd be worried about what they would think of me.  I'll just leave with a comparison with "Murmers of the Heart".  "Murmers" shocked me in a bad way.  The scene I saw take place in present time let me ponder how disasterous this young boy's life would become in the future.  In "Talk to Her" I was shocked but I saw a better tomorrow.  I'm just not sure whether to thank Almodovar or blame him.

I've mulled over my fascination with this film many times.  It was the first Almodovar film I had ever seen, and it still remains my favorite.  There is something very special about this masterful film, something that continues to lay haunt to my soul.  The universal themes explored here seem to layer themselves over time, building upon their foundation an even stronger and deeper exploration of all I thought it had to say.

This film keeps giving.

`Hable con Ella' revolves around two men as they bond over similar situations.  Both Benigno and Marco are in love with women in comas.  Marco's girlfriend, bullfighter Lydia Gonzalez, is thrown into a coma after she is gored by a bull.  Alicia, a beautiful dancer, has been lying in a coma for four years thanks to a car accident.  Benigno is the nurse who has been taking care of her.  While they were never `together', Benigno has fallen in love with her over the years and has come to consider her his soul mate.  He lives and breathes to be near her and talk to her.  Both men have separate yet related struggles.  Marco is struggling with his relationship with Lydia, wondering what he really meant to her.  Benigno struggles with a reality he isn't willing to face.

At the core of `Hable con Ella' is a story about the need to be a part of someone, of something greater than ourselves in order to feel whole.  As these two men bond over their situations they become intertwined in ways neither could have imagined.

What I appreciate about this film is that it understands how to introduce shocking extremes without taking one out of the film.  I read a complaint the other day by a so called Oscar blogger who mentioned that this film was one of the worst films of the decade.  His complaint was this:

"I really don't understand why people like this film. The main character does something TERRIBLE, and we're supposed to feel SORRY for him? I certainly didn't. I think he got what was coming to him. I don't mind the gross sexual stuff that Pedro Almodovar does. I just mind it when he asks me to root for a complete pervert. I just don't understand this film's screenplay win."

This is totally narrow minded and completely misses the entire point of this film.  What Pedro does here is far from ask us to invest in a pervert, but he asks us to understand the mind of the lonely and come to terms with someone's understanding of love and expression.  We don't have to agree with the actions (and hopefully we don't) but like any good, constructive and provocative film, `Hable con Ella' understands the importance in understanding.  When one watches a film like `Dead Man Walking', do we not sympathize and or come to feel heartbreak for Sean Penn, despite his despicable actions?  This is a film about humanity and the imperfections that make us human.  Benigno is suffering, and while he makes some disturbing decisions, one must bare in mind that he is, in fact, suffering.

The relationship that forms between Benigno and Marco is one that speaks volumes to me, for it is one that is ambiguously profound.  While Almodovar leaves a lot of questions open, he understands that that is part of the journey for the audience.  We are left pondering the meaning of their bond and just what one meant to the other.  Marco's reaction to Benigno's actions is a serious point for reflection.

But am I giving too much away?

I urge you to sit down and really delve into this stunning film.  Pedro Almodovar really understands not only his characters but also his audience.  He knows how to paint a picture so vivid and so real that we are bound to relate, if we are willing to be that open and honest with ourselves.

The Bottom Line:

Talk to Her is without a doubt a well-made motion picture, but it's a difficult film to approach and I felt while watching it that I was appreciating its merits without being truly involved with the storyline; I recommend it to people who typically enjoy what are considered "art films" but if that moniker scares you off then seek out another film.

Pedro Almodovar's 2002 film HABLE CON ELLA is one of the film-maker's most elegant achievements. Benigno (Javier Camara) is a nurse in a Madrid hospital taking care of Alicia (Leonor Watling), a young ballerina who has lived in a coma for the last four years. Marco (Dario Grandinetti) is an Argentinian journalist who watches in horror as his torero girlfriend Lydia (Rosario Flores) falls into a coma after a bullfighting tragedy. The two men form an odd friendship, with Benigno's unwavering love for his ward contrasted with Marco's emotional turmoil. HABLE CON ELLA was the film sensation of the year that I moved to Spain, and I watched it many times then and later. After a recent viewing, I decided that I can fairly declare it to be a masterpiece.

HABLE CON ELLA succeeds on several different fronts, from strong acting by this international cast to the bold use of colors and the cinematography. But for me the most memorable are the two psychological tricks Almodovar works in the plot. He inspires such sympathy in the viewer for Benigno, a character who upon rational reflection is arguably monstrous. Then, at the close of the film, he provides what seems like a heartwarming happy ending even when tragedy has unfolded for much of the film. On my recent viewing, I was especially touched by Marco's insightful musings on love in the last flashback scene.

Almodovar's movies are often full of odd sexual twists, a fact with which this reviewer is well acquainted and quite used to. For viewers unused to the Spanish auteur, things may initially seem bizarre, but I would call on everyone who likes art cinema to give HABLE CON ELLA a chance.

In spite of being driven to the top rank of art cinema directors with his critically acclaimed sensation "About My Mother," and being unlike other directors of equivalent status who have been chosen to work within the rootless world of the international co-productions, Almodvar has remained instilled in the rich culture of his native Spain...

In "Talk to Her" the two main protagonists are men, unusually for Almodvar, whose films have been notable for a succession of powerful and striking female roles... Benigno is a male nurse who is employed to care for a dancer (Alicia) in a coma after a car accident... At the private clinic he meets Marco, a journalist who is in love with Lydia, a female bullfighter also in a coma after being gored by a bull... They become friends and Benigno persuades Marco that he must talk to Lydia, even if she cannot hear (therefore the title). But then we lean that the likable and amiable Benigno has raped Alicia, the woman who is in love with her...

European art cinema has a great tradition but an uncertain future in the world increasingly dominated by Hollywood... Almodvar is an ornament of European culture which proved that the form still has much to say about the human condition and can say it with charm, elegance, and attractiveness...
